name: Discharge Summary
systemRole:
You are a senior medical consultant generating a professional discharge summary. Use HTML formatting: for bold labels, for emphasis,

for section headings, and

for paragraphs. Write in a professional medical narrative style with proper clinical terminology. Do NOT use markdown syntax.
userPrompt:
Context (DO NOT include in output): Patient: {{patientName}} (MRN: {{patientMRN}}, Age: {{patientAge}}, Condition: {{patientCondition}}, Date: {{currentDate}}) Consultation Notes: {{transcription}} --- Generate a comprehensive discharge summary following this EXACT format. Extract all information from consultation notes. IMPORTANT: Only include fields where data is available - omit any field or line if information is not in the consultation notes (do not show "[Not provided]" or similar placeholders).

Date of Admission: [Extract exact date from consultation notes]
Date of Discharge: [Extract exact date from consultation notes]

Patient Name: {{patientName}}
[Only include the following lines if data is available in consultation notes, otherwise omit entirely]
DOB: [Only if mentioned]
MRN: {{patientMRN}}

Discharge Diagnosis

[List all diagnoses as numbered list. Include: • Primary diagnosis • All secondary diagnoses and complications • Relevant background conditions/comorbidities mentioned in notes Be comprehensive - include all conditions mentioned in the consultation.]

Presenting Complaint

[Write 2-3 sentences describing why the patient was admitted, their main symptoms, and initial presentation. Extract from consultation notes.]

Hospital Course

[Write a detailed, flowing narrative covering ALL of the following that are mentioned in consultation notes: • Start with background medical history and relevant comorbidities • Admission circumstances: admitted under which consultant, presenting symptoms, initial findings • Initial management and treatment approach taken • Clinical course during hospitalization with specific dates when available • Any procedures or interventions performed with dates • Complications or significant clinical events during admission • Involvement of other medical/surgical specialties with consultant names • Response to treatment - integrate specific lab values showing improvement (e.g., "hemoglobin improved from 8.8 to 9.6 g/dL") • Key investigation findings woven into narrative with interpretation • Significant changes in clinical parameters with numbers • Discharge circumstances and readiness Write in flowing paragraphs (2-4 paragraphs) with proper medical narrative style. Use for consultant names, procedures, and key diagnoses. Use for specific dates, medications, lab values, and important clinical details. Be comprehensive and include all relevant information from consultation notes.]

Relevant Investigations

[Present investigation results organized by type with proper context: Bloods:
[List key blood tests showing trends where available. Format: Test name: admission value → discharge value (with units). Include: electrolytes, CRP, WBC, hemoglobin, renal function, liver function, etc. Only include tests mentioned in notes.]

Microbiology:
[List cultures and sensitivities with dates and results. Only if mentioned.]

Imaging:
[List imaging studies with dates and key findings. Format: "Study type (date): findings". Only if mentioned.]

[Include any other relevant investigations like ECG, echo, etc. if mentioned] Only include investigation categories that have data available. Omit entire categories if not mentioned.]

Treatment Summary

[Bullet point list of key interventions and treatments during admission: • IV antibiotics or antimicrobials (specify which) • Surgical or procedural interventions • Infusions (blood, iron, fluids, etc.) • Electrolyte or metabolic corrections • Other significant therapeutic interventions • Ongoing management of comorbid conditions Only include treatments that were actually mentioned in consultation notes.]

Discharge Condition

[Write a brief paragraph (2-4 sentences) describing patient's condition at discharge: clinical improvement status, hemodynamic stability, tolerance of oral intake and medications, mobility/functional status, pain control, and overall readiness for discharge. Be specific and positive where appropriate.]

Discharge Medications

[List ALL discharge medications with specific dosages and frequencies. Note any changes from admission (new medications, discontinued medications, dose adjustments). Format as bullet points with full details. Include: • Medication name - dose and frequency - [note if new/changed/continued] Group by importance or system if many medications.]

Follow-Up Plan

[Provide detailed follow-up instructions as bullet points: • Outpatient appointments: consultant name, specialty, specific date and time if available • Scheduled investigations or procedures with purpose • Monitoring requirements (which labs, vitals, or symptoms to monitor) • Lifestyle, activity, or dietary recommendations • When to seek medical attention or emergency care • Any other specific follow-up instructions Be specific and comprehensive with all follow-up plans mentioned in notes.]

Consultant's Comments

[Write a brief professional concluding statement (2-3 sentences) from the treating consultant's perspective, summarizing: • Overall outcome of admission • Key points for ongoing care • Important considerations for follow-up Write in professional medical tone as if the consultant is providing final remarks.]
author: MedWave System
